What is a process in an operating system: A process is a program in execution that has its own memory, CPU time, and system resources.
What is the difference between a process: A process is an independent program with its own memory space, while a thread is a lightweight unit of execution within a process that shares memory.
Process scheduling is the method by which the OS decides which process runs next on the CPU using algorithms like FCFS, SJF, and Round Robin.
What is a deadlock?: A deadlock occurs when two or more processes are waiting for each otherâ€™s resources and none of them can proceed.
What is virtual memory?: Virtual memory allows the OS to use part of the hard drive as RAM to extend physical memory, enabling larger programs to run.
What is a system call?: A system call is a way for user-level programs to request services or resources from the kernel.
What is the purpose of the scheduler?: The scheduler selects processes for execution to ensure CPU utilization and fairness.
